title: Title
content:
To add a title or subtitle, use:
```
# Title 1
## Title 2
### title 3
#### Title 4
##### Title 5
###### Title 6
```

title: Emphasis
content:
To add emphasis to the content that will be written, use the asterisk * or underline _:
- Bold: add two asterisks `**text**` or two underdashes `__texto__` at the beginning and end of the content.
- Italics: add only an asterisk `*texto*` or an under-dash `_texto_` at the beginning and end of the content.

title: Links
content:
There are two ways to insert a link in Markdown, through a direct link or using anchor text:
```
Anchor text: use the characters [](), adding the text you want to appear in braces
and in parentheses, the destination address, in the format [example](https://example.com/).

Direct link: Wrap the web address in braces <>. The address will be visible and clickable by the user.
The address in the form of a direct link has the format <https://example.com/>
```

title: List
content:
For unordered lists, use a hyphen - or an asterisk * in front of the list item:
```
- Item 1
- Item 2
- Item 3
  - Item 3.1
```
The above unordered list will be displayed like this:
- Item 1
- Item 2
- Item 3
  - Item 3.1

For ordered lists, use the item number followed by a period. :
```
1. Item 1
2. Item 2
3. Item 3
```
The above ordered list will be displayed like this:
1. Item 1
2. Item 2
3. Item 3

title: Images
content:
The code for inserting an image into content is similar to the code for inserting anchor links, adding an exclamation mark ! at the beginning of the code, as in the example below:
```
![Alt or image title](Image URL)
```

title: Quote
content:
To transform text into a quote or comment, similar to the HTML `<blockquote>` code, use the > sign at the beginning of the line that will be formatted:
```
>This is a *blockquote*. The signal used opens and closes this code in HTML.
>To add another line to the citation, just press Enter for a new
>signal code. This will generate a new paragraph inside *blockquote*.
>**Bold**, __italic__ and <https://links.com> codes work here.
```
How it appears in the HTML:

>This is a *blockquote*. The signal used opens and closes this code in HTML.
>To add another line to the quote, simply press Enter for a new
>sign code. This will generate a new paragraph within the *blockquote*.
>**Bold**, _italics_, and <https://links.com> codes work here.

title: Code
content:
There are two ways to add code snippets to Markdown:

- **Inline code**: add a grave accent ˋ at the beginning and end of the code.
- **Multiple lines of code**: surround lines of code with three backticks ˋˋˋ or three tildes ~~~.

This is a line that contains a `code`.
```
This is a line of code
```

To specify what type of language is being presented in the code block by adding the name of the programming language after the ˋˋˋ or ~~~, for example ~~~javascript or ~~~ruby. See the examples below:

~~~javascript
This is a line of code in Javascript.
~~~

~~~php
This is a line of code in PHP.
~~~

~~~html
This is a line of code in HTML.
~~~

title: Table
content:
Choose column titles and use | to delimit the columns. Then, use a hyphen - in the second line to indicate that the column titles are above, using | again to delimit columns. See an example below:
```
Example | Example value
- | -
Example 1 | R$ 10
Example 2 | R$8
Example 3 | R$7
Example 4 | R$8
```
As it appears:
Example | Example value
- | -
Example | 1 R$10
Example | 2 R$8
Example | 3 R$7
Example | 4 R$8

To specify the type of alignment you want to have in tables, use `:` next to the horizontal hyphen field `---`, in the second line of your table. See below:

- **Left aligned**: use`:` on the left side (default alignment);
- **Right aligned**: use`:` on the right side;
- **Centered**: use`:` on both sides.

See the example:
```
Left aligned | Centralized | Aligned to the right
:- | :-: | -:
Value | Value | Value
```
Left aligned | Centered | Right aligned
:- | :-: | -:
Value | Value | Value

title: Horizontal Line
content:
To define a horizontal line add at least three asterisks (*), dashes (-) or underscores (_) to the beginning of the line (The line must contain only the chosen characters).
```
***
---
___
```
